text: Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, we might need, if it’s something that frequent, we might need a port. Yeah, that’s a lot of beating up on you. You know, once every three weeks Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: you can get away with that and it’s like an hour but if you’re here twice a week it’s pretty painful. Patient: That’s possible that I don’t have to do that, right? Doctor: Well, you could always say no. You could say listen, I just want the chemo and I don’t want the vitamin C trial, just you know forget it and we would just do straight chemo. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Now is it down the road? Is it something that you plan to do or does it matter? Or how would you know that the cancer is shrinking? Patient: That the cancer is shrinking. Doctor: So if his PSA drops. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he’s not on a clinical trial, I don’t get new pictures. Family Member: Ah, okay. Okay. Doctor: Because my sense is if you are well and your PSA’s down I assume the cancer is shrinking. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So in this study there is a random allocation of the therapy and random also means that neither the physician which is me nor the patient which is you knows So it truly is random. And also the computer program flips the coin so to speak, you can only flip it once, you can’t continue to flip over and over until you get the condition you want Patient: Okay. Doctor: So option one is what we call observation. Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it. Patient: Yeah. I understand. Doctor: So here with the observation we are SBRT and you have a crossover. The crossover goes from the observation group to the therapy group. Okay. The crossover is basically gonna happen whenever or if the PSA level decreases by fifty percent of baseline. Patient: The baseline meaning my initial baseline – have to begin with or the baseline for this? Doctor: Baseline for this trial. Patient: The baseline for this would be somewhere around twenty-eight. Doctor: Correct.

text: Patient: But that’s a pretty significant consideration. Doctor: Yes oh absolutely and you know you have the exact indication for requiring Xtandi now. My concern is is it worth it because the Xtandi really did take us too far in terms of giving you control from the cancer. So honestly for the Lynparza I would really push for getting the Lynparza… Patient: The Lynparza is the uh inhibitor? Doctor: Is the pills. The PARP inhibitor. Yes. For the BRCA mutation. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct. Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter)

text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: the IV it’s about an hour. How’s that for fancy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s FDA approved for a cool, hundred thousand dollars so your insurance has to say yes number one, now don’t look at me with those eyes of yours. Secondly, we help you through that so that’s on us and if it’s not approved you won’t get it because people can’t, there’s no way we can afford that so we just would leave that but I might just start there to see if we can get the insurance to cover it. Most insurances will cover it, most insurances. So, that’s one. Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Now, the study that goes with that it isn’t whether you get the medicine or not, that’s a done deal, our study is to know what happens to your immune system so every time we see you we take ah blood from you so that we measure. Okay, what is this guy who’s supposed to fight this kind of infection. What’s his level? And what about this gal’s cell? What was she supposed to do? You know, it’s like who’s sleeping on the job Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and then we check you for a period of a year because we want to know. Same thing like the flu shot is only good for a finite time, right, like this much time is in it. Well, we know every year you have to re-up on that flu shot. We have no idea about this medicine. It’s a one and done. So, our patient’s sign up for, hey I wonder what’s going on in nine months or a year after the fact. So, we hope you participate in that because it’s important for us to know so that’s one treatment option. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: Now, after we do that, a month after that I rescan you again because by then it’s already about ten, twelve weeks that’s passed, almost three months, and then we see what the scans are when they’re done; if they’re worse, the same, or sort of the same. So, that’s all your two choices. Um, and if it’s not or if your PSA is now going whoa, it’s really up there, we normally then will say okay, we either got to commit to chemo Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or pills. Now, chemo and pills are FDA approved. Kind of just like when you had the chemo before Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Typically, we don’t use that medicine unless it drops. Huh, over the long haul, you might get, huh, injury to the longest nerves in your body. Those are your fingertips and to your toes. Huh, you get numbness. Huh, so we try to go out as many as ten cycles. Most people notice it by the sixth or seventh. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if your shirt’s coming in and it’s unbuttoned, even though you tell me you did, I’m not going to believe you. Okay? I have ways to check. Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Because I don’t want to go too far with the numbness, huh, if that’s a possibility. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One of the things about the positive thing about the vitamin C is there is some bit of the people get less numbness. Huh, normally after three or four doses of the chemotherapy, huh, we have a sense of whether it’s helping. Your PSA may be lower. Your pain may be better. Huh, huh, those are sort of some of the clues. Okay? Huh, if we feel like it’s, you are getting better, we’re going to keep going as far as ten treatments. Huh, if after three or four doses, your pain’s worse, your PSA is higher, huh, I might even get scans after the fourth cycle to follow your lymph nodes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, because if your PSA is going up, and your lymph nodes are getting bigger, we’re not going to keep giving you the chemotherapy if it’s causing all those side effects. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself?
conv6019_1-snip8.displayed_text: Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself?

text: Patient: Just in general, I guess. Doctor: Yeah, I think you know, before you make any switch, I would say we touch base, have you touch base with our financial counselors to make sure that you're optimized with everything. I mean, you know, trying to think how old are you? Patient: How old am I? Patient: The older you get the harder it is to remember. I'll be 64 in November. Doctor: So when you qualify for Medicare, is it now or you have to be 65? Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
